Award.AwardTitle: Online and Networked Education for Students in Transfer Engineering Programs (ONE-STEP)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to discover then disseminate tablet computer based teaching methods for engineering preparatory courses in community colleges. The project will finalize development of materials which can be used for both face-to-face and distance education courses, support training of community college faculty in using these materials, and investigate the barriers to adoption of the materials in community college classrooms.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be the creation of networks among faculty who seek to overcome the challenges associated with offering high quality pre-engineering content at a range of community colleges. The project, if successful, will help to increase the number of community college students who successfully transfer to four-year engineering programs. Of particular note is the project's plan to impact a significant number of economically disadvantaged students and students from underrepresented groups who are enrolled in high numbers in community college programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ONE-STEP (Online and Networked Education for Students in Transfer Engineering Programs) is a collaborative project among community college engineering programs in California to improve community college engineering education by aligning engineering curriculum, enhancing teaching effectiveness using technology, and increasing access to engineering courses through online education. The project includes a Summer Engineering Teaching Institute designed to assist community college engineering faculty in developing a Tablet-PC-enhanced model of instruction, as well as developing and implementing online engineering courses. The project also involves a  partnership among California community college engineering programs to design and implement a Joint Engineering Program that is delivered online.

The Summer Engineering Teaching Institute (SETI) has been developed to help California community college engineering instructors use various Tablet-PC-enhanced models of instruction. The SETI curriculum includes the following: a) using Tablets for class lectures, b) video capture and sharing, d) classroom formative assessment, e) developing a technology-enabled interactive classroom, f) flipping the classroom, g) synchronous online and face-to-face delivery, and h) developing online labs. For the three-year duration of the grant a total of 91 community college engineering, math, and physics instructors from all over California participated in the SETI. Participants came from the following institutions: Allan Hancock College, Cabrillo College, California State University Los Angeles, Cañada College, Chabot College, College of Marin, College of San Mateo, College of the Canyons, College of the Sequoias, Evergreen Valley College, Foothill College, Las Positas College, Long Beach City College, Los Angeles City College, Los Medanos College, Mission College, Modesto Junior College, Monterey Peninsula College, Moorpark College, Ohlone College, Pasadena City College, San Francisco State University, Santa Ana College, Santa Rosa Junior College, Skyline College, Southwestern College, West Valley College, Willow International Center (Reedley College) and Yuba College. A survey of SETI participants indicates that the most commonly perceived potential barriers for the adoption of promising teaching practices are a) time required to implement them, b) cost, and c) lack of support from colleagues.

The main goal of the Joint Engineering Program (JEP) is to better serve engineering students in California community colleges by aligning engineering curriculum at partner institutions and increasing student access to lower-division engineering courses through distance education. The  number of collaborating community colleges involved has increased from 6 in 2010-2011  to 19 in 2012-13. Engineering faculty from these colleges were involved in aligning the lower-division engineering curriculum and developing online courses delivered through CCC Confer, a multipoint videoconferencing system that is available for use free of charge to all faculty and staff of the California Community College system. JEP partner institutions are: Allan Hancock College, Cabrillo College, Cañada College, College of Marin, College of San Mateo, Cosumnes River College, East Los Angeles College, Fullerton College, Las Positas College, Los Angeles Pierce College, Mission College, Monterey Peninsula College, Moorpark College, Sacramento City College, Santa Rosa Junior College, Ventura College, West Valley, and Yuba College. Since 15 of these colleges are federally designated Hispanic-Serving institutions (HSIs), the project is contributing to the broadening the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM. A total of 14 online courses were offered at four of the JEP institutions for the 2012-13 academic, and additional ones are currently in development.
